Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as e19e97e247880345aefdf51f557cf1f18d25a5bb
Actually in PCM, certIDs are always integers

Yep that's right, but limiting ID to be an integer string is unnecessary here. In getCertificateProperty(), it calls std::to_string() to convert the integer back to string. This patch simply moves the convertion from function implementation to parameter.
Ack

my motivations are a few reasons:
1. Be consistent in our usage of dbus interfaces.  yes, phosphor-certificate-manager today only produces integers, but we don't have that guarantee, and people copy/paste code from other handlers when they build new ones..
2. Remove the usage of boost::lexical_cast in the code, per the coding standard.
3. Avoid a condition where if we get a certificate that's not an integer, we now fail.
I didn't dig into the children patches. But in the high level, could you explain why we need this change? Are there new backends whose object.filename() are not integers?

The next patch elimates the std::to_string() calls when calling getCertificateProperties() by not enforcing the id to be an integer here. Currently the handlers calls getIDFromURL() to extract the id integer, after this change, we can use the id integer string directly in the argument of route callback.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/54297

This removes the unnecessary "id in url is integer" check to make the program more general. If one day PCM supports non-integer id, bmcweb will not break.
sdbusplus simply returns error when object.filename() is not found, no matter it's integer or else.

It also removes the boost::convert usage in bmcweb, reducing the binary size

There is also a patch Ed submiited before. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47220 We are essentially doing the same thing.
Ack. SGTM
Validator?
Generally you don't want to +1 a change that you're asking for changes on.  +1 means "this looks good"
Fine. Revoked.
Done
Pending validator test
